Paper_Info.Title: Bridging Pre-Training and Simulation: Enhancing AI Performance with Unity ML-Agents
Paper_Info.Review_Status: 2. I/ITEC 2025 Paper Review: Final Acceptance at Paper Review

Session_Info.Session_Title: SIM 2: Reality & Abstraction in Modern Simulation

Relevant_Personas.Rationale: Strong alignment with research in RL, model abstraction, and graph neural architectures applied to training sims. Advanced methods, theory references, and validated experiments with Unity ML-Agents/RIDE support publishable insights and collaboration with DoD labs.

Applied, advanced treatment of AI OPFOR design with concrete integration patterns (Unity ML-Agents), performance/cost tradeoffs, and evaluation methods. Directly useful for technical leaders benchmarking approaches and informing team roadmaps.

Addresses scalable AI behavior generation, fidelity vs. cost, and model-mismatch risk—key for program execution and technical oversight. Offers metrics and methodology to inform requirements, test plans, and simulator integration strategies.

Provides insight into technical maturity, compute/training timelines, and risk from abstraction-to-simulator mismatch—useful for crafting evaluation criteria and requirement language for AI OPFOR. Technical depth is high but yields actionable considerations.

Highlights a productizable approach to AI-driven OPFOR and faster iteration via pre-training with proven Unity integration and Army STTC involvement. Useful for strategy and partnerships, though the paper’s depth is primarily technical.

Illustrates modernization themes (AI OPFOR, scalable COA generation, personalization) with clear efficiency gains and integration into existing Unity-based environments. Good for strategic awareness and risk framing, albeit technically dense.
Offers a concrete end-to-end example of applying RL to military simulation, from abstract pre-training to Unity fine-tuning. Strong learning value despite advanced math and algorithms.
Good exposure to applied RL, graph-based models, and defense simulation transition pathways. Educational and career-informative, though the content is advanced.

Persona_Analysis.Summary_Assessment: This is an advanced, research-grade paper on accelerating multi-agent RL for AI OPFOR via abstract pre-training and Unity-based fine-tuning. It will strongly appeal to researchers and mid-career technical practitioners, while also offering meaningful insights for government program and acquisition stakeholders on maturity, cost, and risk. Early-career attendees and students can learn from the end-to-end workflow and DoD-relevant integration, but should expect dense methods and math. Overall, it is a solid fit for I/ITSEC’s AI and training modernization interests, with clear applicability to scalable behavior generation in simulation.

Paper_Info.Title: Simulator of Theseus: Substituting parts for a Memory Safe Simulator
Paper_Info.Review_Status: 2. I/ITEC 2025 Paper Review: Final Acceptance at Paper Review

Session_Info.Session_Title: SIM 6: Simulation Platforms & Interoperability Architectures

Relevant_Personas.Rationale: Advanced, applied guidance on migrating C/C++ simulators to Rust for memory safety directly supports a tech leader’s goals to stay on the leading edge and improve delivery. Offers concrete FFI patterns, risk-based migration prioritization, change management, and performance data they can apply and collaborate on with peers.

Aligns with lifecycle, cost/risk, and sustainment priorities by presenting an incremental, policy-aware path (Five Eyes/CISA) to reduce vulnerabilities without degrading performance. Useful for shaping requirements, vendor questions, and cross-service coordination; engagement is attend and apply.

Clarifies viability and risk tradeoffs of adopting memory-safe languages in legacy simulators with an incremental strategy and FFI design considerations. Supports better requirement language on cyberworthiness and evaluation of vendor transition plans; engagement is attend and collaborate.

Offers strategic framing for cyber resilience and a low-risk modernization path that can differentiate proposals while preserving delivery. Technical depth is high, but the business implications for positioning, pipeline, and partner vetting are clear; engagement is attend and sponsor/internalize.

Provides an actionable roadmap for hardening products and meeting defense cyber expectations via Rust and FFI with existing C/C++ components. Applied/advanced content helps build transition credibility with primes and PMs; engagement is attend and apply/collaborate.

Supports modernization and cyber-resilience objectives with a pragmatic pathway to reduce simulator attack surface while maintaining performance. Though technical, takeaways inform policy emphasis and program direction; engagement is attend and sponsor initiatives.

Offers hands-on insight into Rust, FFIs, and memory-safe simulator architecture that connects theory to practice. The level is advanced but learnable via the examples and migration steps; engagement is attend and apply under mentorship.

Bridges secure-systems research and applied simulator engineering with FFI design, benchmarking, and change management—useful for guiding student work and industry collaborations. Advanced/applied level; engagement is attend and collaborate.

Persona_Analysis.Summary_Assessment: This paper is an advanced, applied treatment of making simulators more cyber-resilient by incrementally replacing C/C++ components with Rust via FFIs, backed by rationale, tools, and performance data. It will resonate most with technical leads and mid-career government/industry practitioners who influence architecture and requirements; it is also useful to acquisitions and executives for understanding risk, policy alignment, and transition feasibility. Accessibility is reasonable for engineers (with concrete examples and tooling), but less suited to first-time generalists or operator-focused attendees.

Directly supports strategy for training modernization in a new operational domain (SDA), covering TNA/TMA, XR/AI, and MDO scenarios. Applied/advanced level suitable for decision-makers. Engagement to attend, task teams to explore pilots, and collaborate across services/industry.

Bridges theory and practice via literature-based TNA/TMA, fidelity/validity metrics, XR/AI, and measurement (e.g., eye tracking). Advanced/applied level matches research interests and transition paths. Strong collaboration and publication potential; attend and collaborate.

Provides a concrete competency map and skill taxonomy for SDA operators, useful for workforce planning and upskilling. Technical level is introductory-to-applied for talent strategy. Practical for applying to hiring profiles and partnering with training providers.

Offers user needs, competencies, and media selection considerations (fidelity/validity) to inform requirements and risk. Applied level fit. Useful for market research and shaping eval criteria, though it lacks TRL/MRL and contracting detail; attend and collaborate.

Useful to benchmark against emerging training architectures (XR/AI, battle lab/MDO) and fidelity/validity practices. Applied/advanced technical level fits tech leads seeking methods to bring back to teams; attend and apply.

Good overview of SDA mission context and exposure to XR/AI training, measurement, and competency frameworks. Introductory-to-applied level supports career exploration and research interests; attend and seek mentors/internships.

Persona_Analysis.Summary_Assessment: This perspective paper maps competencies and training media for Space Domain Awareness, blending a literature-based TNA/TMA with applied examples (XR/AR/VR, serious games, AI agents), facility concepts, and fidelity/validity considerations. It is accessible to applied/advanced audiences without heavy math and is most appealing to senior government/coalition leaders, researchers, workforce strategists, and industry developing space training solutions. While it does not provide empirical validation or acquisition mechanics, it offers a clear framework and opportunity areas that fit I/ITSEC’s focus on training modernization, interoperability, and tech transition.

While the sample size and scope temper immediate transition claims, the results and methods provide actionable guidance for designing, evaluating, and piloting adaptive training within I/ITSEC’s defense training ecosystem.

Persona_Analysis.Summary_Assessment: This paper is an advanced, applied MR + AI guidance study in a UH‑60 training context, featuring a modular ROS-based backend, knowledge graphs, LLM-driven adaptivity, and neuroadaptive workload measures. It provides strong technical depth with empirical results and a formal evaluation, making it highly appealing to researchers and senior technical leads and moderately valuable to government program and acquisition staff seeking evidence and cost/benefit signals. Students and early-career engineers gain rich exposure to human–machine teaming and MR system design, though the technical level is advanced; direct procurement or policy details are limited.
